FOR_BIZ.FIRST: As a business owner, you have a million things on your mind ‚Äî a feeling that has only been amplified by the coronavirus. Right now, one of your main concerns may be how you‚Äôre going to stay afloat when customers aren‚Äôt out and about, either due to state regulations or personal health concerns.
FOR_BIZ.SECOND: We get it. We are the sons, daughters, and friends of small business owners who‚Äôve been struggling under the weight of this pandemic, and we want to help.
FOR_BIZ.THIRD: That‚Äôs why we created Community Carecard. It allows your customers to support you by buying a digital gift card now to redeem for goods and services later. We designed our process to allow any business to participate, even if you don‚Äôt have a website.
FOR_BIZ.GET_STARTED: It's free and simple to get started:

ONBOARD_FLOW.STEP_0: Fill out a quick form to claim to business
ONBOARD_FLOW.STEP_1: Verify you‚Äôre the business owner via email
ONBOARD_FLOW.STEP_2: Link your bank account to Stripe to enable direct deposits
ONBOARD_FLOW.STEP_3: Share your Community Carecard page with your customers!

FOR_BIZ.FOOTER_1: Ready to start selling digital gift cards? Registration takes less than five minutes.
FOR_BIZ.FOOTER_2: Check out our <1>Resources page also for additional resources on navigating the coronavirus pandemic.

ABOUT.PARAGRAPH_1: We are the sons and daughters of small business owners, the students cramming for final exams in the back of your cafe, the starving artists you include in open mic nights, the ones you make beautiful every time we leave your salon. Together, we‚Äôre better as a society because you are the cornerstone of our local communities.
ABOUT.PARAGRAPH_2: When we needed you to be open ‚Äî to fix that broken nail, to massage away our stress, to pour us a glass of much deserved wine, to feed our families ‚Äî you were there, and now we want to be open for you.
ABOUT.PARAGRAPH_3: We‚Äôre a diverse team (Google, Airbnb, entrepreneurs, engineers, designers, and even the Twitter FailWhale Inventor!) committed to building a platform that enables you to sell gift cards digitally, whether or not you‚Äôre set up to do it today. Since we know your focus is ‚Äî and should be ‚Äî on your family, teams, and customers, we‚Äôve made our onboarding process simple, allowing you to prioritize what truly matters.

CONTACT.HEADER: We'd love to hear from you
CONTACT.DESC:
If you have a question, idea or comment about Community Carecard, email us at <1>{{email}}

You can also visit our Frequently Asked Questions.

HOW_IT_WORKS.WHAT: Community Carecard is a way to support local businesses by purchasing a digital gift card. This gives them cash now in exchange for goods or services later, helping them ride out the coronavirus pandemic.
HOW_IT_WORKS.STATS: With 7.5 million small businesses facing the possibility of permanent closure, it‚Äôs essential we rally around the mom-and-pop shops who make our hometowns whole.
HOW_IT_WORKS.SELL: With that in mind, our team of volunteers has created a process that lets any small business start selling digital gift cards, even if they don‚Äôt have a website.
HOW_IT_WORKS.STEP_0: Find a business you‚Äôd love to support
HOW_IT_WORKS.STEP_2: Check out securely with Stripe, and receive your gift card via email
HOW_IT_WORKS.STEP_3: Your money‚Äôs sent immediately to the business owner
HOW_IT_WORKS.STEP_4: Redeem your gift card in the future

HOME.TESTIMONIAL_0: Closing my business was tough but supporting my staff and family during this difficult time is what keeps me up at night. We cannot work remotely and need to generate revenue ‚Äì the Community Carecard allows us to do that. We are not a digitized business, so we did not have a way to sell gift cards but we also needed something easy to implement. The ability to receive gift card sales will allow us to pay operational costs and support our team until we can reopen.
HOME.SEARCH_MAIN: Support a small business now by buying a gift card

HOME.SEARCH_TEXT_TWO: Coming soon: more features that let you find your fave local businesses, like searching by location and category

GENERAL.A: Community Carecard is a way to support local businesses that have been affected by the coronavirus pandemic. By purchasing a gift card online, you‚Äôre giving your favorite local business money now in exchange for goods or services later. This immediate cash flow will help sustain businesses during closures or slow sales caused by this unprecedented situation.

Though Community Carecard is the brain trust of several small business enthusiasts, it really took shape when Lee Anne Grant, Chief Business Officer of The Assembly; Mike McCormick, an Associate Partner at Great Point Ventures; and former Googlers Paul Huynh and Peter Szalontay brought their respective projects together. They all share a passion of finding effective ways to build and sustain communities, amplify compassion and humanity, and connect people to make the world a better place.

The Community Carecard team is supported by a group of impassioned leaders who have come together online since the outbreak via different COVID help networks and incubators. We‚Äôre truly a global and diverse team, with members located in San Francisco, Colombia, London, and beyond. Let us know hello@ccarecard.com if you‚Äôd like to help us deploy to more businesses in your area.

GENERAL.Q: I am a member of the press, how can I learn more?
GENERAL.A: Please contact us at hello@ccarecard.com, we‚Äôd love to find ways to partner with you and help spread the message to support our local businesses.

SUPPORTERS.A:
Three very easy steps:

Support: Find your favorite local business by name or zip code. Purchase a gift card or give a tip ‚Äî the business gets paid immediately
Share: Show the business owners you support them ‚Äî and show your neighbors how they can help ‚Äî by sharing on social
Enjoy: Feel good about helping a local business and, once it reopens, enjoy its services by redeeming your Community Carecard.

SUPPORTERS.Q: Are these like regular gift cards?
SUPPORTERS.A:
Yes and no. If you buy a $100 Community Carecard today, you‚Äôll be able to redeem it for $100 worth of goods or services when your favorite local business reopens.

But, it‚Äôs important to note that our gift cards are one-time use only. Translation: If you have a $25 gift card to your favorite restaurant, but only spend $22 at dinner, you will not be able to use that $3 balance at a later date.

That‚Äôs not because we‚Äôre trying to fleece you; that‚Äôs because we‚Äôre trying to get this initiative off the ground quickly ‚Äî and get your money to the business owners who desperately need it. We‚Äôve worked our way around this issue by offering an array of gift card denominations. At your local coffee shop, for example, we‚Äôd advise buying five $5 gift cards rather than one $25 gift card.

We‚Äôve also built in the ability to ‚Äútip‚Äù a business, which is basically a way of showing your appreciation and support.

While you won‚Äôt receive goods or services in exchange for your tip, you can feel good knowing you‚Äôve helped a deserving entrepreneur (and their hardworking staff) during a tough time.
Please note, donations to for-profit businesses are not tax deductible.

SUPPORTERS.Q: How do I choose which local businesses to support?
SUPPORTERS.A:
With all the deserving local businesses out there, we know it can be hard to narrow your list. We suggest starting with the shops and stores that you love and visit most. Search for them on our site.

After you‚Äôve taken care of your favorites, consider other businesses in your community ‚Äî like local bookstores and salons ‚Äî that social distancing rules and closures may have hit the hardest.

SUPPORTERS.Q: Is there another way I can support a business besides buying a gift card?
SUPPORTERS.A:
Yes! You can spread the word about Community Carecard to businesses and customers alike. Encourage local businesses to sign up (it‚Äôs free for them!), and encourage your friends and neighbors to support their favorites.
We also offer a ‚Äútipping‚Äù option, where your money goes straight to a business‚Äô bank account ‚Äî without the requirement or expectation of future services and goods. This is a very generous way to give back to your local community favorites.
Of course, this is a community affair ‚Äî so if you have any recommendations for how we can work together to support local businesses, please let us know at hello@ccarecard.com.
No, but we encourage you to redeem them as soon as your favorite shops reopen for business.

SUPPORTERS.Q: My favorite business isn‚Äôt listed ‚Äî what should I do?
SUPPORTERS.A: Our list of businesses is pulled from Google‚Äôs database of 150 million places around the world. Using this system allows us to include as many businesses as possible. While we can‚Äôt currently add any businesses that aren‚Äôt on this list, we may offer that feature in the future.

SUPPORTERS.Q: Does Community Carecard charge fees to local businesses?
SUPPORTERS.A:
Nope! Today, we‚Äôre solely focused on providing relief to local businesses and directing as much financial aid to them as possible.

When you buy a gift card or send a tip, our payment processing partner charges a small fee (2.5% + $0.30). We add this amount to your purchase so that 100% of your money goes directly to the local business you love.

The Community Carecard team is staffed entirely by volunteers, though we accept and encourage donations to offset our operating costs. You can help us continue to grow by checking the ‚ÄúSupport Community Carecard‚Äù box at checkout.

SUPPORTERS.Q: Can Community Carecards be used to make online purchases?
SUPPORTERS.A: Community Carecards were created to support in-person purchases at brick + mortar locations and cannot be used for online purchases at this time.

SUPPORTERS.Q: What happens if the business never reopens its doors? Do I get my money back?
SUPPORTERS.A:
While we hope that Community Carecards will enable every local business to weather the coronavirus pandemic, we know that may not always be the case.

Yet, because we immediately funnel the funds from your gift card purchase to the business itself, Community Carecard cannot issue refunds if the business folds.

That sucks ‚Äî there‚Äôs no way around it. But, if it happens, we hope you‚Äôll take heart in the fact you did your part to keep local businesses alive.

BUSINESSES.Q: Why should I participate in the Community Carecard program?
BUSINESSES.A:
We believe in strength in numbers and the power of community.

The more businesses that sign up for Community Carecard, the more awareness we can generate ‚Äî and, hopefully, the more customers who will participate. While you can, of course, sell gift certificates over the phone, many customers (cough, millennials) are more comfortable with digital purchases. Additionally, imagine a world where you can sell gift cards even while you‚Äôre asleep at night, that‚Äôs what our platform can bring to your business!

Our seamless implementation process allows you to start selling digital gift cards in under five minutes, without you having to make any phone calls, wrangle any software, or pay a single cent. We‚Äôre in this for you.

For every  transaction, revenue generated from the sale of gift cards will be instantly transferred to the business bank account or debit account verified by you (business owner) during the Community Carecard registration process.

BUSINESSES.Q: How can I add my business to your site?
BUSINESSES.A:
We‚Äôre delighted you‚Äôre on board! To list your business with Community Carecard, please click ‚ÄòRegister my Business‚Äô at the top of the page. We‚Äôll work with you to verify the listing and get you up and running ASAP.

Once you‚Äôve been verified with Community Carecard (we just want to make sure you‚Äôre the rightful owner), we will send you a link to start the simple registration process with our partner Stripe Connect which will enable you to assign your bank details so you can get paid via direct deposit. In a matter of a few clicks from start to finish, you will be set up and ready to not only sell digital gift cards but also receive payments directly to your designated bank account

PS. Since we‚Äôre staffed by volunteers and working with as many business owners as possible, your patience is greatly appreciated.

BUSINESSES.Q: How can I get my customers to buy gift cards?
BUSINESSES.A: We‚Äôre living in unprecedented times, and everyone‚Äôs looking for ways to help ‚Äî including your loyal customers. We encourage you to share your Community Carecard profile through your regular channels: social media platforms, email newsletters, even a big sign in your window. In your communications, make sure to express how the coronavirus has affected your business and how digital gift card purchases are vital to helping you stay afloat.

BUSINESSES.Q: When will customers be able to start redeeming their gift cards?
BUSINESSES.A: Ideally, your loyal customers can redeem their gift cards as soon as you reopen. Otherwise, we‚Äôll set a tentative date of May 1st, 2020.. With the uncertainties ahead, as well as your ability to resume normal operations being tied to government restrictions, we‚Äôll work with you to create a strategy that benefits both you and your favorite customers.

BUSINESSES.Q: How can I track gift card purchases and redemptions?
BUSINESSES.A: Today, you will receive an email notification for each gift card sold with a unique code, name of purchaser, date purchased and the amount purchased. In the future, we are working to develop a more robust system to help you track and manage the purchase and redemption process. We would love to work with you to better understand your needs as a small business owner and build out a comprehensive system to deliver for you.

BIZ_RESOURCE.DESC: The coronavirus pandemic is affecting small businesses in a variety of ways. We‚Äôve highlighted some resources to help businesses like yourself navigate this challenging time. Please keep in mind, information is constantly evolving, so please refer to each site for the most up-to-date information.
BIZ_RESOURCE.FOOTER: Quick note: This is not to be taken as tax, legal, benefits, financial, or HR advice. Since rules and regulations change over time and can vary by location, consult a lawyer or HR expert for specific guidance.
